{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3536875,"name":"","username":"SmartKirb99","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/e495f1/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-23T02:19:32.330Z","cooked":"

Hi, so our team, currently building the final-ish robot for our first competition at Kettering, decided to use LEDs, I am unsure as to how I would program LEDs on a command based robot. I’m completely unsure as to how I would program LEDs in Java. I believe the team is planning to use a Rev Blinkin as well.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-02-23T02:19:32.330Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":136,"readers_count":135,"score":77.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492797,"topic_slug":"trying-to-program-leds-in-a-subsystem","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63914,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Co-Captain"},"post_url":"/t/trying-to-program-leds-in-a-subsystem/492797/1","custom_user_title":"Programming Co-Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3537025,"name":"Steven Carmain","username":"Steven_Carmain","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/f07891/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-23T04:33:55.009Z","cooked":"

We have a LED subsystem in our logic, you can see how it works there too, as there are a bunch of commands. This example might not be fully useful as we base ours on the WpiLib AddressableLED class, not the Blinkin, but you can see how we structured the subsystem and commands.

Honestly a demo with the device from somewhere else might be useful too. It looks like you make a PWM Spark “motor” to command the device, and you just send the % listed in the table here (page 14) https://www.revrobotics.com/content/docs/REV-11-1105-UM.pdf . Then you could just have a generic subsystem with commands that drive a “PWM motor”.

github.com

RobotTemplate/src/main/java/org/livoniawarriors/leds at main ·...

A baseline to start our robot projects. Contribute to FRC2832/RobotTemplate development by creating an account on GitHub.

PS: We’ll be at Kettering week 2 with you guys as well!

Hi, if you are using the rev blinkin

You need to create a spark controller in your code (I will name it ledstrip for this example)

then you should make a method for the leds (for testing you can write in the robot)

Than try to do
If (driverController.a().getasboolean()) {
Ledstrip.set(0.43) //or what ever color you want
}
Else if () {}

And you know the rest just remember to connect it to the pwm port in the roborio

Here is the color pelte
REV-11-1105-UM (1).pdf (523.1 KB)

Looking at the replies, both seem like great options. Assuming that the Rev Blinkin uses the Spark class, it might be easier if I try to make a flowchart. I believe I plan on the following:

led.drawio592×582 21.5 KB

Really the only reference of a Blinkin I have is the chassis robot that was Mantis (Our 2023 robot)

In terms of LEDs our team has, we have 12v with wires that appear to plug into each other, and have 4 wires, with the colors black, green, red, and blue. A 5v strip in pretty rough shape, with 3 wires going into a connector, being white, green, and red, and two branching wires that are red and white, and blue, what appears to be tape, on the back. A 5v strip with 2 connectors, with black, green, and red wires, and has a backing that says 3m on it. And also a 12v with what appears to be an orange backing, and a plug type I do not recognize, as such I call this wire the odd wire

Our team used a blinkin for LEDs last year, We created a subsystem to handle most of the logic with the ability to set the pattern we wanted displayed, though I think we ended up with just an On/Off setup in the end.

We then had a default command setup that took suppliers for when it should trigger that state of the LEDS.

I decided to look at the code, and although I have yet to test if they will work. I kind of want to test out something along the lines of if the match type is, like say, qualification and elimination (I pulled those from the DriverStation class), to make the LEDs a different color.
